awd_titl_txt: Information and Communication Technologies, Employee Engagement in Innovation, and Team Innovation Process
awd_abstract_narration:
Many jobs in today's economy are dependent on information communication technology (ICT). This includes traditional e-mail and telephone communications, as well as new and evolving technologies like videoconferencing, instant messaging, and social media tools. ICT is often used for coordination and cooperating across different corporate units. ICT also makes it easier for many employees to quickly and efficiently share their knowledge and plans. Altogether, ICT could be very advantageous for producing innovation. At the same time, there could be drawbacks such as information overload or lack of attention to more focused formal communication channels. As a result of these concerns, this research aims to determine how ICT facilitates employee engagement in innovation, how ICT interacts with formal communication methods, and how the general social climate for innovation changes the ways that ICT affects work processes. With this knowledge, organizational decision makers will have better ideas of what to expect when new ICT systems are implemented, and have a better sense of what activities might emphasize the advantages and minimize the disadvantages.

This research aims to address three key research questions. First, how does ICT use shape employee engagement in innovation process, and in turn influence individual-level emergent states and outcomes? Second, how does ICT use interact with formal communication structure to shape intra- and inter-team dynamics in communication and knowledge creation, and to impact team-level emergent states and outcomes? Third, how does organizational climate for innovation shape the influence of ICT use on organizational innovation processes and outcomes? This project contributes to the literature by providing a theoretical model that explicates the influence of ICT use on individual and team innovation processes, extending the stream of literature on organizational learning by clarifying the most significant dynamic process, examining how organizational climate for innovation influences the effects of ICT use on innovation, and providing a clearly specified and rigorous mathematical model that facilitates future extension and integration with other theoretical models of learning and innovation. The project takes a multi-method approach, including computational modeling, laboratory experiments, archival data analysis, and a field study.

por.por_cntn:
Information and communication technologies (ICTs) have allowed organizational members to collaborate across formal boundaries between organizational units and exchange ideas without face-to-face interaction (e.g., exchange emails and contribute to shared on-line documents). This project aimed to address three core research questions: (1) how ICTs shape employee engagement in innovation and impact individual employees, (2) how ICTs relate to intra-team and inter-team interpersonal interactions and team outcomes, and (3) how ICTs, organizational climate, and organization innovation relate to each other. In addition, to extend the core research questions, we aimed to examine the unique role of new hires in the team learning and innovation processes.

This project took a multi-method approach to answer these questions. First, we created a computer model that included representations of individual workers’ learning processes and their interactions with coworkers that are supported by ICTs. Using computer simulation, we examined the trajectories of the emergent individual and team knowledge structure, task performance, and creative performance, for different team tasks and different combinations of team member characteristics. Second, we conducted experiments and collected data from human participants who worked on a creativity task. Data collection from human participants was approved by the researchers’ institution’s Institutional Review Board (IRB) and informed consent was obtained from participants. Participants were randomly assigned to teams that differed in task instructions, access to collaborative tools (particularly document sharing), and virtual versus in-person work conditions. Participants’ experiences and behaviors were captured by surveys, video recordings, and each team’s work outputs. Third, we analyzed archival data collected from a large sample of organizations over multiple years to examine how employee technology use, organizational innovation, and organizational climate for learning influenced each other over time. In addition to answering the specific research questions, we developed and validated new measures and developed other new methods in this project, including methods for theory development, data collection, and data analysis. 

This series of studies addressed our research questions. First, regarding the first two questions, we found that attributes of ICTs interacted with workers’ characteristics to impact individuals and teams in the innovation process. For example, we found that in both in-person and virtual teams, availability of document sharing was more likely to improve team’s output when teams had members with weaker individualist values. We also found that individualist value was related to individual members’ negative mood states and developing clear understandings of their roles within the team, and the negative impact of individualist values was most amplified when individuals worked in virtual teams or asked to share documents in in-person teams. The negative mood state and the lack of clarify about one’s role in the team could in turn relate to avoiding teammates and sharing leadership duties. As for the third research question, we found that employee technology use and organizational innovation could positively reinforce each other and positive change in climate for learning was consistently and positively related to increase in technology use. In addition, these relationships between employee technology use and organizational innovation varied across organizations with different formal practices, such as human resource management practices. Finally, in a series of studies, we found that the interactions between new hires and old-timers and among new hires themselves could affect new hires’ learning and adjustment as well as how effectively the team could adjust to the arrival of new hires.

By addressing these substantive research questions and developing new methods, this project contributes to several areas of research in organizational science (including research on learning, innovation, teams, and newcomer adjustment). The methods developed could potentially impact other areas of research related to organizational science, such as research on individuals' well-being and family experiences. In addition, multiple undergraduate and graduate students have worked closely with the researchers in this project, including students from under-represented groups in science and technology. Research experiences provided by this project could help prepare these students for their future careers in academic and industry jobs. Further, the collaborative team task developed and used in this project can be used for class activities when covering team, leadership, and creativity related topics. Last but not least, this project provides insights for managers and organizational leaders with a more in-depth understanding of the influence of ICTs on knowledge sharing and innovation, which could support them to more effectively and efficiently implement ICTs in organizations. As for individuals in the broader society who work in teams and use ICTs at work, this project helps them understand how ICTs interact with other work conditions (e.g., virtual vs. in-person) and individual differences among coworkers to shape interpersonal dynamics at work and team outcomes. Taken together, findings from multiple studies in this project underscore the importance of effectively managing human resources in addition to implementing and managing ICTs for organizations to stay innovative.
